author: Jeff Whalley
title: Customers were warned, says ANZ chief | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The
text:
OUTGOING ANZ chief Mike Smith says Australians should not be surprised they are being asked to pay more to fund a safer banking system.
The outspoken banker says increased costs for borrowers and weaker returns for shareholders were tipped when the reform process started more than a year ago.
Late last year, Mr Smith and then Westpac chief Gail Kelly warned consumers and investors would likely bear the burden if banks were forced to set aside more cash.
Speaking to Business Daily yesterday, Mr Smith said all the banks “copped a bit of flak on capital raisings”.
“As I said last year, if this happens someone is going to pay for it,” he said. “And at the time everybody said ‘no that’s not the case’. But it is simple economics.”
Mr Smith was speaking after the Federal Government yesterday unveiled its formal response to the Financial System Inquiry report handed down last December by inquiry head David Murray.
The Government backed Mr Murray’s call for the banks to have “unquestionably strong” capital buffers.
The banking regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, has since heaped pressure on the major lenders to set aside billions of dollars more to guard against a future financial crisis.
Mr Smith yesterday also backed Westpac chief Brian Hartzer, who was roundly criticised last week for hiking home loan rates out of cycle with the Reserve Bank to help pay for regulation.
“He’s taken a bit of a battering which is probably a little unfair,” Mr Smith said.
“The fact is if you are forced to raise capital, somebody has to pay for it.
“This stuff doesn't come free — the choice is either the customer or the shareholder or a combination of both.”
Commonwealth Bank chief Ian Narev welcomed the Government’s response, saying he agreed Australian banks should be “unquestionably strong” and recognised as such.
The Government said it accepted APRA’s push to ensure banks bolstered their books.
Mr Smith said the guidance from the Government suggested most of the “heavy lifting” had already been done by APRA in terms of capital buffers, but there was still “fine tuning” to take place.
He cautioned that the latest set of global guidelines around banking capital would “take a few years to sort out”.
Mr Smith declined to say whether further rate hikes were likely by Australian banks without a lead from the Reserve Bank. “I couldn’t possibly comment on that,” he said.
Australian Bankers’ Association chief Steven Munchenberg said customers would share some of the burden as banks raised capital.
“I know people won’t see it like this when they are sitting around their kitchen table looking at their mortgages, but in many ways that extra cost is an investment in the security and safety of Australia’s economy in the future,’’ Mr Munchenberg told Sky Business.
Among other initiatives in response to the Financial System Inquiry, the Government said it would look into different systems for allocating default superannuation funds, and ban “excessive” surcharges on credit and debit-card transactions.
It will also introduce legislation to improve standards in the financial advice industry.
